messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:04): adds another example of extension to the FAQ
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:15): can someone explain to me when you use "same origin" and when you use "non same origin"?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:16): sorry
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:16): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: http://validator.whatwg.org/ has the old name of b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9's service
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:16): when you use "same origin" and when you use "same-origin"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:17): you use "same origin" when "origin" is the last word in the phrase, and "same-origin" when that forms a single adjective form for another noun.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:17): so "this is the same origin" and "this is the same-origin policy"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:17): great, thanks
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:31): does the same apply to "server side"?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:32): google says it does
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:43): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: we're probably going to keep our pixelratio impl
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:50): shouldn't HTML5 say "in an ASCII case-... manner" rather than "in a ASCII case-... manner"?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (13:50): i.e. an vs a
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:57): gets confused when an email entitled "250 years of Robert Burns" turns out to be about the Scottish poet
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:12): hmm, finds "WebSocket is cross-origin." shouldn't cross-origin there have been without the dash?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:12): having to edit a technical spec with terms that are not in common usage in English sucks
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:14): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Same_origin_policy ...
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:15): i seem to remember chaals saying that there were no rules and people do it both ways
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:15): yeah, that might be correct
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:18): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyphen#Compound_modifiers has advice
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:19): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: The Chicago Manual of Style has rules
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:19): it seems you can do it safely without for same origin and cross origin
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:19): albeit the rules have a weird thing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:20): CMoS says it's Civil War‚Äìera rather than Civil War-era
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:20): en dash vs. hyphen
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:20): which would make the name of the spec "Cross Origin Resource Sharing"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:20): yeah, Wikipedia has a bunch of that stuff too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:21): which seems fine, since Cross does not modify Resource or Sharing in any way, right..?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:21): I'd have written Cross-Origin Resource Sharing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:21): but I don't have a specific rule to appeal to
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:22): i'd like to either consistently use a hyphen or consistently not or have a rule that says when to use it and when not
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:22): and have it somehow made clear when that rule applies and when not...

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:28): I'll do cross origin and same origin for now, point that out on the list when I've done my edits and ask for advice there so someone can bikeshed it and everyone can be happy
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:29): actually, never mind, it's going to be too much of a hassle
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (14:36): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e2, "Cross Origin Resource Sharing" mean "Angry Origin Resource Sharing". :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:36): fair enough
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:36): I'm edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e again btw, not edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e2 :p
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (14:37): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, oops, legacy content problem
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:37): fortunately I'm more HTML than XML; maybe even more flexible, as I don't think <html2> means <html> in any user agent
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (14:38): fwiw, cross-threaded describes when a nut and bolt are misaligned, or the lid for a bottle
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (14:38): so there's a precedent for cross-something
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (14:40): cross-ply tyres have a structure which goes back and forth and is stacked up in layers
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:41): There's cross-examining and cross-checking etc too
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (14:42): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, oh yeah...I guess there's a whole class of cross-something compounds as a precedent for cross-origin.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:42): but those probably aren't relevant since they're not used as adjectives
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:44): or maybe they're not relevant because the adjectival form (cross-examined etc) is a normal adjective prefixed by "cross-"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:45): whereas "origin" is never an adjective, so "cross-" is not just a modifier of that word; it's making a whole new word instead
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:46): this is going to be a major game-changer: http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20090114-nokia-qt-lgpl-switch-huge-win-for-cross-platform-development.html
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:46): you guys should review my drafts for spelling :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:47): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: What value would be added to your documents by having them spell-checked?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:48): (There's no point spending much effort being correct solely out of a desire to be correct :-) )
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (14:49): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, I don't really see the problem with the current name. Though I don't really care that much if it's renamed

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (14:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, you could use a spelling checker? (If your HTML editor doesn't do spell checking, you can copy-paste the text into a word processor, then correct the source from what the word processor finds.)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:50): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, less room for ambigiuity, as 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 pointed out
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:50): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9, I suppose...
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (14:50): only worth doing that once it's pretty stable, though
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:50): are there any good open-source English grammar checkers?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:52): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: LGPL Qt sounds pretty nice - I couldn't find any alternatives to wxWidgets when writing a GUI for a not-quite-open-source project, so it's good if Qt is now usable in those situations
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:55): I wonder what the chances of getting a unified Linux desktop are now
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:56): well, with Android underway, having just one is not quite going to happen I think
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:56): though maybe Android will never be for desktop despite the rumors

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (14:57): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, some Googling reveals a couple of open source grammar checkers but both were 0.x rather than 1.x versions. Also found this rather pessimistic description about the lack of success in this area: http://faq.cooldictionary.com/english-grammar-checker.php
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:57): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Things seem to be moving in the opposite direction - I have Gtk applications, Qt3 applications and Qt4 applications
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:59): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: is Android's GUI toolkit on the Java layer on the one below?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:59): supposes it'd be easy to argue that grammar checkers destroy our language, by discouraging anyone from writing anything interesting and non-formulaic
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:59): on the (fake) Java layer
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:59): afaik
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (14:59): that was the "disadvantage" of it, all popular Linux apps wouldn't run on it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:00): at least according to the articles I read; and given what they write about HTML5, I'm somewhat suspicious :p

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (15:01): I'm getting used to the Google icon, but for some reason I keep thinking it's for organic milk or fruit juice or something of that ilk...maybe that's a good look to have captured.
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (15:01): those things are the epitomy of not being evil, after all
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (15:02): oh, maybe the reason is dark green along the bottom and bright blue along the top
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (15:02): I guess the red is like a sunset and the yellow like a corn field, too

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (15:05): the new one has rounded corners! it's web 2.0!
